title: When doctors say “COVID-19 may be here to stay even with a vaccine” that doesn’t mean we’ll never go back to normal, does it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, that could very well mean that we'll never go back to normal. I am a nurse practitioner currently working in an ER in Houston Texas. We have been wearing masks even in the nurses station since the middle to the end of February. We have discussed this exact topic at length amongst our colleagues and coworkers. I'm not sure that we will ever see a time where we can safely walk around without a mask. The covid 19 virus is still very new and we still have a lot to learn about the virus as a medical community, But one thing that we do know for sure at this point is it does not seem to be affected by warm weather like the flu virus. With that in mind it is very possible that this virus will continue to spread throughout the world and it may become just something that is a everyday thing. The thing about viruses as they're very quick to mutate. They are made of simple RNA sequences which allows them to mutate and adapt much more quickly than even bacteria which are single celled organisms. Just think about how long the aids virus has been affecting the human population. We are just now starting to get a handle on it and being able to treat it properly to get viral loads down to an undetected level. Why this is important is because the aids virus affects the T cells in the human body. The T cells in a human's immune system aid in developing immunity. Without an immune system to fight it, the aids virus has had no reason to mutate so therefore hasn't changed much if at all since it was first introduced to the human population. So in short the aids virus hasn't had a need to mutate because it kills the body's ability to remember it and work against it and it's taken approximately 40 plus years to develop a treatment that works effectively. Now when you think about covid that has already been proven to have mutated , this virus is likely to continue to mutate and change making vaccine development and reinfection a very likely possibility. Our best guess as a medical community at this point is the coronavirus will be here for a very long time and will hopefully end up mutating in a way that makes it weaker rather than stronger so that we can overcome it. But if you're asking if I think that we will get back to a normal that we enjoyed in late 2019 I highly doubt that will occur anytime soon. So get used to your masks and get used to a different way of life. I wish you and everyone the best of luck and I hope you stay safe out there. Remember there's a lot more to this virus then what the mainstream media portrays and it is certainly survivable for most people. Use due diligence and common sense and hopefully as a society we can over come this.
